resources.text: There are multiple file types which can come into play when we are developing Java applications.
These are simple text files, marked with the .java extension, so that it's clear that they aren't just any text files, but java source files. Their content is is easily readable.
As you can see, Notepad++ not only opens this simple .java file, but it also recognizes and colors certain keywords.
resources.boxed:
A java source file can't just have any name. Such a file can contain at most one public class and the filename must be the same as this class' name. As for what a public class is, it will be covered in a later chapter, but for now take a look at the image above.

You can see that the file contains public class Main part, and in the top left corner the filename can be seen, which is indeed Main.java.

We don't really have to give too much thought to this rule, as our IDE will always enforce it for us.
resources.text: This is our previous source file, Main.java, now compiled into Main.class

advanced.title: Compile and run from the command line

resources.advanced:
Our IDE will handle the compilation and execution of all our source files, but by default they are done from the command line, by using the javac and the java commands.

See the guide for links about how to compile and run Java code without an IDE.
resources.text: These are compressed files, much like a .zip or a .rar. They are used to package and deploy Java libraries or applications, hence the name, Java ARchive.
<u>Here are a few things that a JAR file can contain:</u>
resources.list:
• A manifest file, inside the META-INF folder, which contains information about the JAR file
  • Compiled java code (.class files) organized into packages
  • Other resources, for example images
resources.boxed:
JAR files also provide a way to start a Java application easily, without the command line. To make a JAR executable all we need to do is add the fully qualified name of the main class to the manifest, like so:

Main-Class: com.learnjava.Main
resources.text: Packages are a way to structure our Java projects. Imagine an application with dozens of source files, all in the same folder. Instead, the recommended way is to organize the classes by function. Packages can not only contain source files, but also other packages as well!
Here is an example project with two packages and two classes (you can think of the class like it's the same as the source file, for now):
resources.boxed:
Package names should contain only lower case letters.

The top level package is usually some domain name, like com or org, then the next package is often the name of the organization, the programmer, or the project itself. After that, the packages are named by the functionality of the classes inside them.

If you examine the above image you can see that it adheres to these conventions.
resources.text: Important: Some package names are restricted for packages in the Java language. These names are java and javax. Avoid naming a package any of these words, or the compiler will refuse to compile your source files.
resources.advanced: Packages provide much more then just structuring the project. They can hide classes inside them, or allow the programmer to have multiple classes with the same name, in different packages.
resources.text: As we can see, the package hierarchy can be resolved with dot characters. The package declaration must always be the first statement of the source code!
resources.boxed:
We don't necessarily need to declare a package. If we don't, the default package will be used, however, this is discouraged.

Most importantly because the default package can't be referenced, and so we won't be able to import classes from it!

For very simple applications with only one package, it's OK to use the default package.
resources.text: If we wish to use code (a class) from another package, we must import it, without this step our code won't compile. Assume we are in the package of the last example (com.learnjava), and we want to use the class Date from the package java.util. The following code shows what we must write:
resources.code:
package com.learnjava;

import java.util.Date;

//Rest of the code...
resources.text: By convention, the import statements follow after the package declaration, at the beginning of the file.
resources.boxed:
There is a special package in the JDK, java.lang. This contains the core classes of Java development (such as String).

Since these classes are so commonly used, this package is auto imported, we don't have to explicitly import it.
